message.content:
<teammate-message teammate_id="team-lead" summary="Standard translations all use "virtue" for 德 — reconsider?">
New data for the 德 discussion. The passage 故失道而后德，失德而后仁，失仁而后义，失义而后礼 (Dao De Jing Ch. 38) has well-established standard English translations:

**D.C. Lau**: "When the way was lost there was virtue; when virtue was lost there was benevolence; when benevolence was lost there was rectitude; when rectitude was lost there were the rites."

**Wing-tsit Chan**: "When the Way is lost, only then do we have virtue; when virtue is lost, only then do we have humanity; when humanity is lost, only then do we have righteousness; when righteousness is lost, only then do we have propriety."

**James Legge**: "When the Tao was lost, its attributes appeared; when its attributes were lost, benevolence appeared; when benevolence was lost, righteousness appeared; when righteousness was lost, the proprieties appeared."

Every major translator uses "virtue" for 德 in this passage. Our decision was "(constitutive) character" instead.

Given this data — does this change your view? Should we:
A) Keep "(constitutive) character" — our reasoned departure from tradition, acknowledged in TN
B) Use the standard "virtue" for the Laozi block quote specifically (since it IS a quotation of a classical text), then switch to "(constitutive) character" when the author begins their own analysis
C) Something else?

Brief response with your recommendation.
</teammate-message>

input.content:
B. Use "virtue" for the Laozi block quote, then "constitutive character" for the author's analysis.

The epistemological reasoning is straightforward: a quotation and an analysis are different speech acts with different translation obligations.

When you quote the Dao De Jing, you're invoking a text that already exists in English. The reader may know it. Using "virtue" connects them to the existing translation tradition — Lau, Chan, Legge — and that recognition is epistemically valuable. It tells the reader "you know this text; now watch what the author does with it."

When the author then shifts to their own analysis and introduces "constitutive character," the terminological departure itself becomes meaningful. It signals: "I am not using 德 the way these translators did. I am re-reading this concept." The contrast between the quoted "virtue" and the analytical "constitutive character" enacts the author's interpretive move.

A TN at the transition point can make this explicit: "The standard English rendering 'virtue' is retained in the block quotation above. In the analysis that follows, 德 is rendered as 'constitutive character' to foreground [the author's specific interpretive claim]."

This is cleaner than Option A (which severs the reader from the entire translation tradition for no gain) and more principled than using "virtue" throughout (which would flatten the author's departure from conventional readings).
input.summary: Option B — "virtue" in quote, "constitutive character" in analysis
